displaytitle: Studies for an execution; Verso: two studies of a supplicant figure
creditline: Bequest of Dan Fellows Platt, Class of 1895

titles.title: Studies for an execution; Verso: two studies of a supplicant figure

makers.displaydate: 1615–1673; born Naples, Italy; died Rome, Italy
makers.displaymaker: Salvator Rosa, 1615–1673; born Naples, Italy; died Rome, Italy

texts.textentryhtml: Rosa’s predilection for scenes of violence is exemplified in this spirited drawing and the one below. In the brutal subject matter and staccato pen strokes, both are indebted to the Spanish artist Jusepe de Ribera, with whom Rosa may have studied in Naples before moving to Rome in 1649. While the sketches on the recto—possibly representing the decapitation of Saint Paul—cannot be connected with a known painting, those on the verso (glimpsed through the right side of the sheet) are studies for one of the kneeling protagonists in the artist’s Martyrdom of Saints Cosmas and Damian altarpiece of 1669 (San Giovanni dei Fiorentini, Rome).

bibliography.boilertext: Felton Gibbons, Catalogue of Italian Drawings in The Art Museum, Princeton University, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1977).
bibliography.citation: Felton Gibbons, Catalogue of Italian Drawings in The Art Museum, Princeton University, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1977)., Vol. 1: pp. 175-176, no. 537 (illustrated in Vol. 2 under the same catalog number)

bibliography.boilertext: Michael Mahoney, The drawings of Salvator Rosa, (New York; London: Garland Publishing, Inc., 1977).
